revised_title: Influence of Temperature and Surface Properties on Friction in Skiing and Sledging
tldr: This article investigates the effect of temperature and surface properties on the friction experienced in skiing and sledging. The author found that static friction on cold snow is high, but when the sliding speed is appreciable, friction decreases to a low value. This low friction is due to localized surface melting caused by frictional heating. The contact angle of water with the surface plays a significant role in determining friction, with surfaces having a high contact angle providing lower friction. The author also discovered that polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) offers very low friction on snow and ice under all conditions.
